Would flash and style have had much to do with the introduction of metal tsuba ?, I am sure that the beauty of a Gold and Silver inlayed piece or a well carved sukashi tsuba would have turned some heads as apposed to a lacquered hide tsuba.

Rich T
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jim Gilbert 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Monday, May 12, 2003 9:03 AM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: unscientific kawa tsuba experiement


  Thanks -- lots of interesting ideas.  Nerikawa tsuba seem to have been in use for at least 200 years, so I'm not sure I'd call them a brief fad.  However, it seems plausible that the tactics of the Muromachi period that lead to more chaotic conditions of massed combat on foot with shorter swords and probably less skilled (and confident) combatants called for a tsuba that could stand up to a cut to its rim, making the nerikawa guard obsolete.

  Jim
